content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice contribution

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: a bit difficult to solve within 5 min, but interesting, however there is still the problem of the binary output  since we could output always 'shadow' for instance & only calculate the lengths of the words.

While printing the word lengths makes the output not *entirely* binary it's still pretty much binary with a separate task of printing the word lengths. I think the problem would be more interesting if instead of "shadow" or "no shadow" you needed to print something else, like the reason they didn't shadow each other.

Also you are missing a visible test case that has words that are same size and different but share some letters (like validator 3).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it can be a bit long to solve but its original and interesting

This CoC is very close to acceptable now, but it still needs more changes, especially in the test structure.

First some easy stuff:
» In the statement, I think "...but corresponding words..." should be changed to "... words in corresponding positions..." (still not sure about this alternative wording either).
» The Output block should be updated to reflect the extra twist you added to prevent binary outputs

Now for the battery of tests:
» Swap the Validators for #1 and #2. By doing so, Set 1 tests three words, and Set 2 tests two words
» Validator #3 should contain three words, where one of the word pairs has a different word length, but at least all word pairs do not share letters
» Set #4 is not good - it needs to be split into several sets
» New Set #4 should have the same number of words of equal length, but the answer is "no shadow" because one of the word pairs shares common letters
» New Set #5 should be "no shadow" because the number of words in the input sentences is different.
» A Set #6 that tests five shadowed words could be nice, though it's probably not necessary
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community and has therefore been deactivated.
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: not so easy but very funny

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I'll just repeat the same things mentioned before and hope you change it.
Binary output should be avoided because you can pass half of the tests just by printing true or false.
"all of the word lengths are the same" should be something like "all of the corresponding word lengths are the same"

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice contribution.
My JS solution : 

r=readline
a=r().split(' ')
b=r().split(' ')
z=a.length==b.length?'':'no '
b.forEach((x,i)=>{if(x.length!=a[i].length||[...x].some(y=>a[i].includes(y)))z='no '})
print(z+'shadow')

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Because you do not take into account XorZy advice.
No binary output https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/contribution-guidelines
It can be to count shadow words in the sentence...
Also the statement is false. When i read "all of the words length are the same" i literally understand that. So only the test 2 should be true

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great ! I like the idea and fun to do.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

As stated in the contribution guidelines, you should avoid having binary outputs like "True" or "False" since it's possible to get 50% without any understanding of the problem.
If you can't find a way to get around that, you should at the very least replace "True" or "False" with language-agnostic flags like "Shadows" or "not shadows" since it can give an unfair advantage in shortest for languages which naturally output "True" or "False" with a capital letter.
I am also of the opinion that the problem is not suited for reverse.
Finally Validator 4 is the only case where the number of words between s_1 and s_2 differs. You should never have edge cases in validators only, as these are usually not visible in game, and all other cases seem to indicate that s_1 and s_2 have the same number of words.

A nice and simple clash otherwise.
Don't think this should be used for Reverse mode, but otherwise an excellent challenge.
Must join to the previous commenters. Challange is great, but validator 3 does not pass, expectation is false there falsely.
It was a great challange thank you.

The code bellow pass all the tests but not validator 3:
s1 = input().split()
s2 = input().split()
s = len(s1)==len(s2)
for a,b in zip(s1,s2):
    s &= len(a)==len(b)
    for i,j in zip(a,b):
        s &= i!=j
print(s==1)


You should change test 3 , so make it fails on test 3. I did this mistake because of the word "common" I was thinking at letters at the same positions.

Moreover I think it's too difficult for reverse mode with this test cases, this code will pass all tests but is very far to check all the rules:
s1 = input().split()
s2 = input().split()
s = len(s1)==len(s2)
for a,b in zip(s1,s2):
    s &= len(a)==len(b) and a!=b
print(s==1)
It looks like a fun problem. Right now I can't approve it, because Validator 3 is not correct. The output should be "True". Reply to this comment when you fix the validator and I will approve it
Agree that reverse mode would be better, and change the description to say "there are no shared corresponding characters". Other than that, this is a winner!
You should clarify, all of the words are of the same length, and *corresponding* words don't share any common letters whatsoever.

Game mode reverse!
 I think it is hard to guess from testcases
What about playing it as fastest mode
Ok
The correct output is False. As the problem says the words must not share any letter. friends and company shares the letter 'n'.
I have adjusted according to your feedback but I could not do set 6 according to your plan because it's a bit too difficult.
cool complement

he is right I didn't even understand this from the statement
and passed all the tests
